[10/10] H.R. 5 must be defeated. 

This attack on LGBTQI+ students cannot prevail.

[9/10] LGBTQI+ students face enough challenges already due to stigma, harassment, and bullying, as well as anti-LGBTQI+ state laws. 

H.R. 5 would exacerbate these challenges and worsen already hostile environments for LGBTQI+ youth.

[8/10] The bill also includes additional provisions that are intended to limit our ability to collect accurate data on the experiences of LGBTQI+ students & would require schools, if asked, to disclose students‚Äô survey answers to their parents, potentially outing LGBTQI+ youth.

[7/10] LGBTQI+, and especially trans, youth are overrepresented in the homeless population because they are kicked out of their homes by unaccepting parents. This bill would put trans youth who have unaccepting parents at risk of being kicked out of their homes.

[6/10] Although many parents support their LGBTQI+ children, not all parents are accepting. By forcing schools to out transgender students, regardless of the harm this could cause to the students, H.R. 5 puts the safety and wellbeing of transgender youth at risk.

[5/10] H.R. 5 includes two provisions that would require schools that take steps to respect a student‚Äôs gender identity to forcibly out those transgender youth to their parents, regardless of if this would put the youth in harm‚Äôs way.

[4/10] During committee debate on this bill, anti-equality politicians made numerous anti-trans comments. 

It‚Äôs not surprising then that H.R. 5 also includes several provisions that were *expressly* included to undermine the rights of LGBTQI+ people.

[3/10] H.R. 5 opens the door to empowering certain parents to dictate what other parents‚Äô children can or cannot read or learn in school. This could especially lead to schools censoring content on topics relating to LGBTQI+ people, as well as race.

[2/10] All children deserve access to a safe and affirming school environment, and all parents, including LGBTQI+ parents, have an important role to play in our education system.

H.R. 5, however, goes against these core values.

Until these problems are mitigated, I will continue to push for a complete moratorium on ALL offshore wind projects. 

There is too much at stake & I will not allow these companies, or this administration, hide behind ‚Äústopping climate change‚Äù as an excuse to destroy our oceans.

The current system in place has allowed offshore wind to move forward too quickly & too recklessly in an attempt to solidify the legacies of green new deal advocates. They hurt the environment, raise energy prices, & will destroy existing industry. 

We must fix this process NOW.

This also has raises major concerns for our national security. The DoD has ruled much of the East Coast as ‚ÄúWind Exclusion Zones‚Äù due to turbine impacts on our long-range air surveillance systems. Yet, BOEM has pushed ahead.

Offshore wind farms have massive impacts on radar systems used by vessels of all sizes. Despite warnings from our own government and outside groups, BOEM has pushed forward with their approvals. 

THIS WILL COST LIVES.

Wind companies come to contractual power agreements with states YEARS before BOEM begins their EIS process. BOEM uses these contracts as excuses to ignore alternative layout requests from stakeholders. 

THE FIX IS IN FROM THE START.

Industrial wind grids also sit right on top of foraging grounds & migration routes for critically endangered North Atlantic right whales. 

Despite warnings from THEIR OWN scientists, BOEM and NOAA have ignored the obvious long term impact these projects will have on marine life.

These industrial wind grids are being leased right in the middle of some of the Atlantic‚Äôs most sensitive environments, historic fishing grounds, and existing maritime transit lanes. 

Wind co's and this admin have ignored nearly every attempt at input from these stakeholders.
Did you also know that BOEM‚Äôs OWN EIS admits that offshore wind will HAVE NO impact on climate change and actually INCREASES greenhouse gas emissions?

In order to lay transmission cables, wind companies will have to dredge HUNDREDS of miles of sea floor. 

Existing BOEM EIS‚Äôs claim this dredging will have the same environmental impact as doing nothing at all. 

Does that make sense to anyone?

The overwhelming majority of the House Republicans will now be on record supporting the idea of expanded federal powers in your child's education. I have no doubt the Democrats will remind them of this poison when they are back in charge and want to pass federal education bills.
This bill suffers from one fatal flaw, however. While seemingly reinforcing parents' rights, the bill undermines the critical principle for conservatives - federalism, the bedrock of our liberty.
The bill includes many worthy initiatives for parents to pursue, including setting bathroom gender policies and allowing parents more access to their children's curriculum.
Congressional Republican have a response for these parents: "Let's allow the federal government to take it from here."

Parents said, "Enough!" and did what has always been a defining characteristic of America's self-governance experiment - they took action at the local level. The parent movement is about one thing: Giving parents more control over their children's education.

There was a growing realization among parents that things had gotten out of hand. Pornographic books in elementary school libraries, Critical Race Theory showing up in math curriculum, and a transgender agenda that erased athletic opportunities for female students.
From Fairfax, Virginia, to Seattle, Washington and school districts in nearly every state, parents demanded answers from their school boards and their teachers.

My mom passed away in 2011 from ovarian cancer, and she didn‚Äôt have health insurance when she was diagnosed. She struggled to afford it because at the time it was totally legal for insurance companies to charge more for patients ‚Äî like my mom ‚Äî who had a pre-existing condition.
I caught sight of my then-Congressman, smiling and beaming with pride that he had just voted to repeal protections for people with pre-existing conditions. When I saw that, something inside me broke.

The ACA is a major part of why I first ran for office. As we celebrate its 13th anniversary, I think back to 2017 as I watched live coverage of the Rose Garden ceremony President Trump held after the House voted to repeal the ACA. https://twitter.com/barackobama/status/1638956749804675109 QT @BarackObama Thirteen years ago today, I signed the Affordable Care Act into law.
